29AD3AB4736D445BB67BB99C8F0E76FC.description:
Detection techniques will be limited to variation in Doppler shift (radial velocity method) and the
transit method.

962E99196CC24F4C9EBF648225CD9226.description: Difficulties in the direct detection of exoplanets.

0A723D52B363450CBE10126F8D4E2264.description: Formation of quasars from active supermassive black holes.

662CED0BAF524CD2BDEF690F6E41ED72.description: Quasars show large optical red shifts; estimation involving distance and power output.

D53EF209272C4D66917BB3857CA74AA2.description: Discovery of quasars as bright radio sources.

AF7E8AED6B8C4D1CBD4D4A35BCC28DE3.description: Quasars as the most distant measurable objects.

DC67FC9070024014B200DCB893A7F0B6.description:
Qualitative treatment of Big Bang theory including evidence from cosmological microwave
background radiation, and relative abundance of hydrogen and helium.

3F0653097AFD478FB9BBAEB2C4D793FA.description: Simple interpretation as expansion of universe; estimation of age of universe, assuming H is constant.

F8B2BF7236054FD6A7B3D4CC760BA837.description: Calculations on binary stars viewed in the plane of orbit.

46730AC7A8854E6BA340D6CDF809FCC2.description:
Δ f / f = v/c
and z =
Δ λ / λ = − v / c
for v ≪ c applied to optical and radio frequencies.

481E8E45F8ED4FDBB2EC887A0E8B81A4.description: Calculation of the radius of the event horizon for a black hole, Schwarzschild radius (Rₛ) , Rₛ ≈ (2GM) / c²

D5FE8E29BC15475DA37BB8E3BCE4FE27.description: Supermassive black holes at the centre of galaxies.

2544CF602D4E4D8C935E45DA26496216.description: Students should be familiar with the light curve of typical type 1a supernovae.

3085D0EEC144480682FC5F306DDF5773.description:
Use of type 1a supernovae as standard candles to determine distances. Controversy concerning
accelerating Universe and dark energy.

2BFCC9AD7C734BB9A80DE790E87A652C.description: Comparison of energy output with total energy output of the Sun.

013CD3BFB32948D0A37C037A79BD5A97.description: Gamma ray bursts due to the collapse of supergiant stars to form neutron stars or black holes.

CBF43ABC673C459E9011695DB59859CA.description:
Defining properties: rapid increase in absolute magnitude of supernovae; composition and density of
neutron stars; escape velocity > c for black holes.

111FE36AA8A34F7AA6B6759AD2253840.description: Supernovae, neutron stars and black holes

3B864C4E6B91498EB01E76BA5ED818D9.description: Stellar evolution: path of a star similar to our Sun on the HR diagram from formation to white dwarf.

D0EFCBF020E74C5F8751CF40A1B27F49.description: Students should be familiar with the position of the Sun on the HR diagram.

55720F46D540464EB3D90C0B4DCD9919.description:
Axis scales range from –10 to +15 (absolute magnitude) and 50 000 K to 2 500 K (temperature) or
OBAFGKM (spectral class).

F85C3D7EE3A64465BB50696DF4BBB400.description: General shape: main sequence, dwarfs and giants.

643AAE912AB84E99A5DEEAE8CD4BD3A2.description:
Temperature related to absorption spectra limited to Hydrogen Balmer absorption lines: requirement for
atoms in an n = 2 state.

341CE5D9421A4C9DAA7291AFC3E8C862.description: Description of the main classes: O, B, A, F, G, K, M

9E9C8B9106144FD9AF982413BCB52FE0.description: Principles of the use of stellar spectral classes

1A46D20147C84D74B78CB0358536CA8C.description: Use of Stefan’s law to compare the power output, temperature and size of stars

0725E81605A0466D962CE5C08E94B47E.description: Inverse square law, assumptions in its application.

C04E1021A9764B92B3520A862761A627.description: Assumption that a star is a black body.

F87C94FAF0C4404D91330C57B203F2FF.description:
General shape of black-body curves, use of Wien’s displacement law to estimate black-body
temperature of sources.

A2669C5863AC41B49F09C3E19666BAAA.description: Stefan’s law and Wien’s displacement law.

8BB3DFC8820A4506BB909ADE07A91E5B.description: Definition of M, relation to m: m – M = 5 log d / 10

81E24D7F00A04547867DFA3D0FC37AA4.description: Brightness is a subjective scale of measurement.

C9B0CD278D4C49A3AA666F1E7B665D11.description:
Relation between brightness and apparent magnitude. Difference of 1 on magnitude scale is equal to
an intensity ratio of 2.51.

7E0FD0C6C7444A408549409C06299DAF.description: Dimmest visible stars have a magnitude of 6.

29179D5553E14B1D8F664E68911CDBB3.description:
Comparison of the eye and CCD as detectors in terms of quantum efficiency, resolution, and
convenience of use.

9BA1DC9FB486455CBE6D6B1AE862BFCE.description: Students should be familiar with the rad as the unit of angle.

5A21CAEC0D6543AA97FDAFC817DCA3BB.description: Collecting power is proportional to diameter²

59837F1387774C36A0531D7E2B8F29E5.description:
Similarities and differences of radio telescopes compared to optical telescopes. Discussion should
include structure, positioning and use, together with comparisons of resolving and collecting powers.

F3143AE5E3D645D7985DFCF32431A9DB.description: Single dish radio telescopes, I-R, U-V and X-ray telescopes

F6815DD62D014DFAA58E7A181B38E8D2.description:
Relative merits of reflectors and refractors including a qualitative treatment of spherical and
chromatic aberration.

518CC33D1EF94CC9B157BB12CBB12FA8.description: Ray diagram to show path of rays through the telescope up to the eyepiece.

18028407B1CB4B0D81275529F047AF0C.description: Cassegrain arrangement using a parabolic concave primary mirror and convex secondary mirror.

0A8096E8A6AD46F89B134FE9A8048343.description: M = (angle subtended by image at eye) / (angle subtended by object at unaided eye)

0018761CF87345D48FA66945F3CB53D8.description: Ray diagram to show the image formation in normal adjustment.

7BFB26FCC8714C90953C64A027611628.description: Astronomical telescope consisting of two converging lenses

33CDD122A7A847DCB4F7436B6DC52C86.description:
Appreciation of balance between risk and benefits in the
development of nuclear power.

516BDBA3EC134973A7BF4DF42503BE20.description:
Production, remote handling, and storage of radioactive
waste materials.

52C69A3FBEB54E988F61A188CA1B9967.description:
Fuel used, remote handling of fuel, shielding, emergency
shut-down.

11F6306440264538BEDE5C7BAEDB05B2.description:
Factors affecting the choice of materials for the moderator,
control rods and coolant. Examples of materials used for
these functions.

CAB71262084A4EBDAA64560A22ED2577.description:
Students should have studied a simple mechanical model of
moderation by elastic collisions.

FF1EE33A1D8F49F58A2F4C08C017993B.description: Details of particular reactors are not required.

80A45C53C42D4F8CA200C403BBAF1A27.description:
The functions of the moderator, control rods, and coolant in
a thermal nuclear reactor.

1BEE23523EE54D35B295252E6452E3AF.description:
Fission induced by thermal neutrons; possibility of a chain
reaction; critical mass.

FAE33E549C5B4B32BFD935CC28CF7ABF.description:
Appreciation that knowledge of the physics of nuclear energy
allows society to use science to inform decision making.

E5B1338B653745BFA83D5FB651E6A48A.description:
Students may be expected to identify, on the plot, the
regions where nuclei will release energy when undergoing
fission/fusion.

4B6F66DB072F4093BAB3B6AAC754A53F.description:
Graph of average binding energy per nucleon against
nucleon number.

AEFD1709C61A4CCBBBFC946DB1B822CB.description:
Simple calculations from nuclear masses of energy released
in fission and fusion reactions.

F467F0A709C24065845808F84274BC04.description:
Simple calculations involving mass difference and binding
energy.

AB390466F6074C30B9248832A2FAAE46.description: Appreciation that E = mc² applies to all energy changes,

5FA86840A6814FE897553F183C4FB370.description:
Students should be familiar with the graph of intensity
against angle for electron diffraction by a nucleus.

450B4155160A45B09F06587680855D2C.description:
Interpretation of equation as evidence for constant density
of nuclear material.

B96CEF04CBE94D009EEFC05EA944947B.description: Dependence of radius on nucleon number: R = R₀A^⅓ derived from experimental data.

BA5E7E37522F454188AE5CB493A3AD36.description:
Students will need to be familiar with the Coulomb equation
for the closest approach estimate.

9E7ACBA8847B49EC96B8B76B31813A8B.description: Knowledge of typical values for nuclear radius.

50AB7AD511DA4E56B6537A42D213E8F0.description:
Estimate of radius from closest approach of alpha particles
and determination of radius from electron diffraction.

18BD046D54E64F5F8320C0298D14E00B.description: Questions may use nuclear energy level diagrams.

0FB36BA314204C9C8F4651258556B688.description:
Changes in N and Z caused by radioactive decay and
representation in simple decay equations.

678FB038D62349BC8FAF5967EF3A4DD3.description:
Possible decay modes of unstable nuclei including α, β+, β−
and electron capture.

10D6E472F8E345C8935556B6B76F72E2.description: Graph of N against Z for stable nuclei.

DB759C685F1C417290DF60A5DE033686.description:
Applications eg relevance to storage of radioactive waste,
radioactive dating etc.

3464AC78DF41459EA3C483675C709FB9.description:
Determination of half-life from graphical decay data
including decay curves and log graphs.

3E301608A1C4491882E3DF2D6189EA10.description:
Questions may also involve use of molar mass or the
Avogadro constant.

5B04E7AFF53048418958B9250C36908E.description: Questions may be set which require students to use A = A₀e^(−λt)

1D63BF2CBAEF4C87AA488EAFECDA70CB.description:
Random nature of radioactive decay; constant decay
probability of a given nucleus;

B1523014BB3445ECB7C557D1616B63E8.description:
Required practical 12: Investigation of the inverse-square
law for gamma radiation.

470394C6310B40E98EE74B180ABE9EC7.description:
Appreciation of balance between risk and benefits in the
uses of radiation in medicine.

FCBEF957AD32416CAC7BE9E4B3886501.description:
Background radiation; examples of its origins and
experimental elimination from calculations.

8ED8C41B5C3F41229D999F919B664E8C.description: Applications eg to safe handling of radioactive sources.

E1E637890BC2401698F9E7FE2496749C.description: Inverse-square law for γ radiation: I = k / x²

D4EA2BA544294EA5AFD00E7A75C75B34.description:
Applications also include thickness measurements of
aluminium foil paper and steel.

665CDAFB5EAF46FBBF6F25ABCEB1A368.description:
Their properties and experimental identification using simple
absorption experiments; applications eg to relative hazards
of exposure to humans.

83133C2E2B54494282EB968DDAEC7C87.description:
Appreciation of how knowledge and understanding of the
structure of the nucleus has changed over time.

FB8D9D1288E64FA2B9255F854815896E.description:
Transmission of electrical power at high voltage including
calculations of power loss in transmission lines.

43A0BA3610154BF7BE3AAD48520A7FEC.description: Causes of inefficiencies in a transformer.

203424C51774431AA2DEE8B242982AAD.description:
The transformer equation: Ns / Np
= Vs / Vp

DA094102A8404C67A229B91B052E2BA1.description:
No details of the structure of the instrument are required but
familiarity with the operation of the controls is expected.

E4061652378643F1A589A5151862CC38.description:
Use of an oscilloscope as a dc and ac voltmeter, to measure
time intervals and frequencies, and to display ac waveforms.

72391C6A14094411A64F129DAF4EBD73.description:
Application to the calculation of mains electricity peak and
peak-to-peak voltage values.

B9E2AE748322436AA6EF277441D0937D.description:
Sinusoidal voltages and currents only; root mean square,
peak and peak-to-peak values for sinusoidal waveforms only.

F68A7101130A4500BAA2CDEC5B79FBA2.description:
emf induced in a coil rotating uniformly in a magnetic field:
 ε = BANωsinωt

B597C79DE8744F6F8360426EA1942C7A.description:
Applications such as a straight conductor moving in a
magnetic field.

CB16B58A8EAF480A9BC0AC0310957D42.description: Magnitude of induced emf = rate of change of flux linkage ε = (N Δ  φ)/ Δ t

69F45A6EBE6041FABFB124574AD0236D.description:
Required practical 11: Investigate, using a search coil and
oscilloscope, the effect on magnetic flux linkage of varying
the angle between a search coil and magnetic field direction.

4DBCAEF458D641158226976D833C5146.description:
Flux and flux linkage passing through a rectangular coil
rotated in a magnetic field: flux linkage Nφ = BANcosθ

E658743437854746875BB73CF556C8F1.description:
Flux linkage as Nφ where N is the number of turns cutting
the flux.

E538624171F1431A8257C721066EED4C.description: Magnetic flux defined by φ = BA where B is normal to A.

9A12AD80938F4795A2610A1A040CACAB.description:
Circular path of particles; application in devices such as the
cyclotron.

7AD77CA9D54249648ED0E78B09F4836F.description: Direction of force on positive and negative charged particles.

DB38A63C496D44A6A5CB821FAB573C79.description:
Force on charged particles moving in a magnetic field,
F = BQv when the field is perpendicular to velocity.

1E3AFC2CD25342F1817653E8507BC825.description: Moving charges in a magnetic field

598BB75846B14250A0C0886AABA048A7.description:
Required practical 10: Investigate how the force on a wire
varies with flux density, current and length of wire using a
top pan balance.

AE19E635068C4F959D76423F2CCE3CCE.description: Magnetic flux density B and definition of the tesla.

D417A46577E34E6FBEF5E44B00E0E238.description: Force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field: F = BIL when field is perpendicular to current.

18FA7CDEE7AF4529808BAD06F6E2874C.description:
Required practical 9: Investigation of the charge and
discharge of capacitors. Analysis techniques should include
log-linear plotting leading to a determination of the time
constant, RC

1E611B1B08C74DAC80C12C4E012EAF35.description: Quantitative treatment of capacitor charge, Q = Q₀(1-e^(− t /(RC)))

DBD827B443414719978900D331E8EB91.description: Use of the corresponding equations for V and I.

384E9D86CAC647BE948A1C26328128F3.description: Quantitative treatment of capacitor discharge, Q = Q₀e^(− t /(RC))

015615C31A834876BD101D64F451A4D6.description:
Calculation of time constants including their determination
from graphical data.

E6629CE35BD24D8F82F2323FEF7DE63E.description:
Interpretation of gradients and areas under graphs where
appropriate.

6591806E58F54B7D97E49CC17D10ACC9.description:
Graphical representation of charging and discharging of
capacitors through resistors. Corresponding graphs for Q, V
and I against time for charging and discharging.

0F680617E67B4982AB9B38A2FD28CD9A.description:
Interpretation of the area under a graph of charge against pd.
E = ½
QV = ½
CV² = ½
Q²/C

DFEEDA419C4B476F9E61D8BACE5B6AEA.description:
Students should be able to describe the action of a simple
polar molecule that rotates in the presence of an electric field.

76599C7433EC4840B22B7CAFF8241B80.description: Dielectric action in a capacitor C = (Aε₀εᵣ)/d

45B8276C07FC4534AA73BFD1BA08BC9C.description: ΔV from the area under graph of E against r.

D2C963B787A04F16882F959A1BEA884B.description: V related to E by E = Δ V / Δ r

A61602EA59B348F5BCAB62AD5CE74B84.description: Graphical representations of variations of E and V with r.

C6817347965441C0B6DDB19305444E2B.description: Magnitude of V in a radial field given by V =  1/(4πε₀) x Q / r

905C4CDE7BED4BA387AB10D39443ACCA.description: No work done moving charge along an equipotential surface.

8330B3BA060D4F62945F21DA4ADAB3E0.description: Work done in moving charge Q given by ΔW = QΔ V

511EF73F4B87472B829E9FF8CE5C32DF.description:
Understanding of definition of absolute electric potential,
including zero value at infinity, and of electric potential
difference.

A0ED9F2490D04490B5A2B6B06DF1A3DE.description: Magnitude of E in a radial field given by E = 1/(4πε₀) x Q / r²

090C80BC4B564CC897B10FD753F76898.description:
Trajectory of moving charged particle entering a uniform
electric field initially at right angles.

89F9FD56E808470987441DB01FA0B755.description:
Derivation from work done moving charge between plates:
Fd = QΔV

A2A189D101904230A505AEF0F69EE8D4.description: Magnitude of E in a uniform field given by E = V/d

3680661935E14D1ABCE6091538E1EDB0.description: E as force per unit charge defined by E = F/Q

1F1EB7F0CA8A4DC6BA773BE5AC6DA7E8.description: Representation of electric fields by electric field lines.

BD6573A9806C4A479B963EE474CC8A7A.description:
Comparison of magnitude of gravitational and electrostatic
forces between subatomic particles.

5BD663AF0B3A4DEE8B7CAB696417C45B.description:
For a charged sphere, charge may be considered to be at
the centre.

29C0E34906EC4BF78ACB8D6E131CFCB8.description:
Appreciation that air can be treated as a vacuum when
calculating force between charges.

59878A3274354261875E7D1B096D46DF.description: Force between point charges in a vacuum: F = 1/(4πε₀) x (Q₁Q₂) / r²

7603BBF2C9B34F2D9BA57E0CF4CD2A52.description:
Use of satellites in low orbits and geostationary orbits, to
include plane and radius of geostationary orbit.

E208B4D7FB4E4906818BAA13FD9ABB56.description: Total energy of an orbiting satellite.

AA8FACFB5CE34BE0ADB43F9FB7CF0EAA.description: Energy considerations for an orbiting satellite.

75EFC22F45CB421F8EBAFC05AC9B1B3A.description:
Orbital period and speed related to radius of circular orbit;
derivation of T² ∝ r³

AFAD582C740D4ABDBC1ECE610FD9D4AD.description: Δ V from area under graph of g against r.

EFE58D82F7F348BC93C3B1AF0602A1C6.description: V related to g by: g = − Δ V / Δ r

5E82C2D859A741D6AB59967171E59F20.description: Graphical representations of variations of g and V with r.

961D65C0812145F48F233E352BCC7F1B.description: V in a radial field given by V = −(GM)/r

3AA5B60D95C547DAACCA491D4D72CEB3.description:
Idea that no work is done when moving along an
equipotential surface.

2870F3167E52470897C336F8DC54A268.description: Work done in moving mass m given by ΔW = mΔV

2CE18D15CA2E42A1BC601AD50C04B5F0.description:
Understanding of definition of gravitational potential,
including zero value at infinity.

8732A00C3F774D5187F81008B8C7B8B4.description: Magnitude of g in a radial field given by g = GM /r²

634BA07E917F48C3B5B42C3BEFB82FC5.description: g as force per unit mass as defined by g = F/m

A90CA3AC7A86410BABEF23CF1961C958.description:
Representation of a gravitational field by gravitational field
lines.

D1998F8016D24B469219911EB0880FC6.description:
Magnitude of force between point masses: F = (Gm₁m₂)/ r² where
G is the gravitational constant.

8E34203524AD41898F56B109DAD34A04.description: Gravity as a universal attractive force acting between all matter.

EBD5015A7E794157AF64DAB936AD6C0B.description:
Similarities and differences between gravitational and electrostatic forces - Differences: masses always attract, but charges may attract
or repel

034FB04A582D40E3805F90FB0CC333BA.description:
Similarities and differences between gravitational and
electrostatic forces - Similarities: Both have inverse-square force laws that have
many characteristics in common, eg use of field lines, use of
potential concept, equipotential surfaces etc

078830A24DA348B9A32643C8413EDB38.description:
Force fields arise from the interaction of mass, of static
charge, and between moving charges.

3D3E8A30BB4742FF9DE9ECD13A5B0D8F.description:
Students should recognise that a force field can be
represented as a vector, the direction of which must be
determined by inspection.

0B9C893D0D934E218FF482F50771946C.description:
Concept of a force field as a region in which a body
experiences a non-contact force.

B9453824DD034C07B94178A2A5CBEB90.description:
Appreciation of how knowledge and understanding of the
behaviour of a gas has changed over time.

D5C7CCF5FE28415B87AA20060A6AA1EF.description:
Use of average molecular kinetic energy = ½ mm(cᵣₘₛ)² = 3/2
kT = (3RT)/(2Nₐ)

5D488EB0F65847BC8BE54D350A32C689.description:
Appreciation that for an ideal gas internal energy is kinetic
energy of the atoms.

A649917A1E8C4B228D7FB8F6750A593C.description:
A simple algebraic approach involving conservation of
momentum is required.

CA7459C223F248189B89518C1C5E5D74.description:
Assumptions leading to pV = ⅓
Nm(cᵣₘₛ)² including
derivation of the equation and calculations.

60C4DAB07CD2448CABE27569872D12AA.description:
Students should understand that the gas laws are empirical
in nature whereas the kinetic theory model arises from
theory.

DB941119A1064A0EB23451E3F3401210.description:
Explanation of relationships between p, V and T in terms of
a simple molecular model.

CE985477D24244A1BB1A25A3856DA649.description: Brownian motion as evidence for existence of atoms.

BA349B71D79248BA83D9CB0DFD0B1C7F.description:
Required practical 8: Investigation of Boyle's law (constant
temperature) and Charles’s law (constant pressure) for a gas.

99C188DDF258451F89D56FBA4873B538.description:
Avogadro constant Nₐ, molar gas constant R, Boltzmann
constant k

6D599355CAA94C7EA4E5168253A9F253.description:
Ideal gas equation: pV = nRT for n moles and pV = NkT
for N molecules.

D257E15AF5FF4B579901BFFB6F4973FD.description: Concept of absolute zero of temperature.

68D74B2C89304DB09102DE8E0C3511A1.description:
Gas laws as experimental relationships between p, V, T and
the mass of the gas.

696F48AA74EB4D1E8293C76ADF14353E.description:
For a change of state Q = ml where l is the specific
latent heat.

DB22B6BC01344136BF86C06EA3266219.description:
For a change of temperature: Q = mcΔθ where c is specific
heat capacity.

30AD48E156DF4E559208D9683B9496B0.description:
Appreciation that during a change of state the potential
energies of the particle ensemble are changing but not the
kinetic energies. Calculations involving transfer of energy.

F76DAAD49F764487B026140D6CAB5FE6.description:
The internal energy of a system is increased when energy
is transferred to it by heating or when work is done on it
(and vice versa), eg a qualitative treatment of the first law of
thermodynamics.

D5369FA6C5F348C888AFA7B1C4ABBCCD.description:
Internal energy is the sum of the randomly distributed kinetic
energies and potential energies of the particles in a body.

7815540539164F39B46435A382CE1CC8.description:
Examples of these effects in mechanical systems and
situations involving stationary waves.

531BF6B8946E487AB7FE6C769FFE3DD1.description:
Resonance and the effects of damping on the sharpness of
resonance.

9332A497461B4AD685D33E3705DE1F51.description: Qualitative treatment of free and forced vibrations.

67C6F087C8E24614A36425D67DA3BFC9.description:
Required practical 7: Investigation into simple harmonic
motion using a mass–spring system and a simple pendulum.

CA18A4031200416EA6985C16B6B4C079.description:
Variation of Eₖ, Eₚ, and total energy with both displacement
and time.

7D8AE033D3FA44EB9CCD20A66FBB5AEF.description:
Questions may involve other harmonic oscillators (eg liquid
in U-tube) but full information will be provided in questions
where necessary.

36A4A294C057425C83B380E4080C3B82.description:
Appreciation that the v − t graph is derived from the gradient
of the x − t graph and that the a − t graph is derived from
the gradient of the v − t graph.

215311139E314E7790A1A563B0E80F2C.description:
Graphical representations linking the variations of x, v and a
with time.

E9FE05AB296D4523860AE23493FD32F6.description: x = Acosωt and v = ±√( A² − x²)

DC09C2E1E67441E7A55C7ADC5277D419.description: Analysis of characteristics of simple harmonic motion (SHM).

A1DD2D03EB144095AEE8746BCDF56932.description:
Magnitude of angular speed ω = vr
= 2π/f

41D8E2C593D54375A585A25282C6D15F.description:
Motion in a circular path at constant speed implies there is
an acceleration and requires a centripetal force.

BB003119DDBA429C82569A42DF235DE6.description: Further mechanics and thermal physics (A-level only)

62FCDC21580845B48E03453F4DAE5B87.description:
Required practical 6: Investigation of the emf and internal
resistance of electric cells and batteries by measuring the
variation of the terminal pd of the cell with current in it.

B277F025FCF64269B9A61112CCFA7025.description:
Students will be expected to understand and perform
calculations for circuits in which the internal resistance of
the supply is not negligible.

A949A0C3ECDF4DB7B0F093D25A789EF0.description:
Examples should include the use of variable resistors,
thermistors, and light dependent resistors (LDR) in the
potential divider.

750D755A67A643ADAFE8E4CEA91609BC.description:
The potential divider used to supply constant or variable
potential difference from a power supply.

FCC4A2D29FE74B27963FCA9E6D6747B8.description:
Conservation of charge and conservation of energy in dc
circuits. (Kirchoff's laws)

99BC1701E4104D3C9128A5B6A8A041BB.description:
The relationships between currents, voltages and
resistances in series and parallel circuits, including cells in
series and identical cells in parallel.

6D1B9E61C7114713914457AFBD9545D2.description:
Energy and power equations: E = IVt;
P = IV = I²R = V²/R

4E0F934562B0481BA5A4BEE460721541.description: Resistors: in series, RT = R1 + R2 + R3 + …

B98AF78F4BAE4F72B1D94FC24D010ED0.description:
Required practical 5: Determination of resistivity of a wire
using a micrometer, ammeter and voltmeter.

BB3EB20A943A4FB5804BF08F323349AF.description:
Applications of superconductors to include the production
of strong magnetic fields and the reduction of energy loss in
transmission of electric power.

0E21CE2BDD94472AAD8FAD7F2A52ABDB.description:
Superconductivity as a property of certain materials which
have zero resistivity at and below a critical temperature
which depends on the material.

D4283407616648FF941BD257C6C3AAE6.description:
Applications of thermistors to include temperature sensors
and resistance–temperature graphs.

C129EA7208D34475966F45250A5DEF3F.description:
Description of the qualitative effect of temperature on the
resistance of metal conductors and thermistors. Only negative temperature coefficient (ntc) thermistors will
be considered.

F79A2D92593440D99347DD5D2F904811.description:
Questions can be set where either I or V is on the horizontal
axis of the characteristic graph.

83DE9ECEE47E442880C0C048B59BEB3A.description:
Unless specifically stated in questions, ammeters and
voltmeters should be treated as ideal (having zero and
infinite resistance respectively).

117100F01EE34CAC9DAF8F088AA9319D.description:
Ohm’s law as a special case where I ∝ V under constant
physical conditions.

62BCDA01293D497C84F9CCCD60020372.description:
For an ohmic conductor, semiconductor diode, and
filament lamp.

82E2950C042B44B49529D7021EC1C138.description: Resistance defined as R = V / I

1BA283A2372942FDA96FE71357880419.description: I = ΔQ / Δ t , V = W / Q

555A5527B52549C5A790A20E64254EB3.description:
Electric current as the rate of flow of charge; potential
difference as work done per unit charge.

338E0B76DDBD4D8CB71402FEA4FA806E.description:
Required practical 4: Determination of the Young modulus
by a simple method.

89AEC58483FE423ABE738D1C716BD9F0.description: (One simple method of measurement is required.)

8BBB8A744EFF41D1ACFB5874B07955E3.description: Use of stress–strain graphs to find the Young modulus.

163B57461E0546178FD02EC1626D8B8B.description: Young modulus = tensile stress / tensile strain = (FL) / (A Δ L)

0C746DFFB69A4FC0BF2EDAF2D3EDACF4.description:
Appreciation of energy conservation issues in the context of
ethical transport design.

D72E38D85B784BEC9DBC6207D41EBB1D.description:
Spring energy transformed to kinetic and gravitational
potential energy.

15949DA54D854670808A97ABA1415484.description:
Quantitative and qualitative application of energy
conservation to examples involving elastic strain energy and
energy to deform.

CEE4B9F6586E41E99648FB5286A2B5FB.description:
Description of plastic behaviour, fracture and brittle
behaviour linked to force–extension graphs.

D748EC73371642E58894943DF8D5CB2A.description:
energy stored = ½
FΔL = area under force−extension graph

D7BA28F56F7246DD8B3D50AC1C2F41DC.description:
Hooke’s law, elastic limit,
F = kΔL , k as stiffness and spring constant.

C356826414B249C8B413DEB430952611.description:
Quantitative and qualitative application of energy
conservation to examples involving gravitational potential
energy, kinetic energy, and work done against resistive
forces.

1F5E1583906C40DA8AEF4785B482159A.description:
ΔEp = mgΔh and Ek = ½
mv²

9B64C06CE31949E7A7B9257C4DC0DF08.description: efficiency = useful output power / input power, efficiency can be expressed as a percentage.

4330B927FD004EC4ABA1D6D4155D7B4F.description: Significance of the area under a force–displacement graph.

565C259EF5F7466D9FA10A526A165177.description: Quantitative questions may be set on variable forces.

8E7A9E1711AC40838AD69114463081E6.description: rate of doing work = rate of energy transfer, P = ΔW / Δ t = Fv

E3E1C5E98FE5469F8F8EB06354A1F35C.description:
Appreciation of momentum conservation issues in the
context of ethical transport design.

F8E15C48DF4B4C7691262FB11DB0418F.description:
Quantitative questions may be set on forces that vary with
time. Impact forces are related to contact times (eg kicking a
football, crumple zones, packaging).

6B4A599A17BA4055A223FE219524A3D6.description: Significance of the area under a force–time graph.

46E88B5F8ED341A681F99F169C2AE99D.description: FΔt = Δ mv , where F is constant.

EE89DBEC2A0B47EA97BFEE69E663574D.description: Force as the rate of change of momentum, F = Δ (mv) / Δ t

D381EC7A35EF40068ED201DC61C4118D.description: Conservation of linear momentum. Principle applied quantitatively to problems in one dimension.

6458E57873AB4FA1ABBE7DD76F1521A3.description: F = ma for situations where the mass is constant.

D9BDB6CA985E4B499925128D7E6AD2C7.description:
Knowledge and application of the three laws of motion in
appropriate situations.

D4DD2E195B5547BFB53D5FECC7573794.description:
Qualitative understanding of the effect of air resistance on
the trajectory of a projectile and on the factors that affect the
maximum speed of a vehicle.

49F9904A51334988AFE2925604A862D3.description: Knowledge that air resistance increases with speed.

0BB48FE692AC45AA804F920754789E64.description: Qualitative treatment of lift and drag forces.

B7E61AF175F3479DB414854EBA41E675.description:
Independent effect of motion in horizontal and vertical
directions of a uniform gravitational field. Problems will be
solvable using the equations of uniform acceleration.

AE46715314A24B11858E558B4367C002.description:
Required practical 3: Determination of g by a freefall
method.

FA5B09BA179049E2B392BC5FF437E62D.description:
Equations for uniform acceleration:v = u + at
s = ((u + v) / 2) t
s = ut + (at²)/2v² = u²+ 2as

1F33AAD661D64FD984EAD0B041EB60F3.description:
Significance of areas of velocity–time and acceleration–time
graphs and gradients of displacement–time and velocity–time
graphs for uniform and non-uniform acceleration eg graphs
for motion of bouncing ball.

67E8C20197674CA7BDCE0F5E06150D19.description:
Representation by graphical methods of uniform and nonuniform
acceleration.

18BE3B541BD1474F8F0C97C530C46D51.description:
Calculations may include average and instantaneous speeds
and velocities.

DBC872EE5CC748A482B3DB09095D9666.description: v = Δ s / Δ ta = Δ v /Δ t

071B7B68B7274AD6ACEFD7E58055853C.description:
Centre of mass. Knowledge that the position of the centre of mass of uniform
regular solid is at its centre.

0D7E381887304F7A8942F4C1A7769A76.description:
Moment of couple defined as force × perpendicular distance
between the lines of action of the forces.

15C194FC7C684A7A8A95229F94C5E419.description: Couple as a pair of equal and opposite coplanar forces.

2E55B26CD4A74F02B6CD3D08D89A8F23.description:
Moment defined as force × perpendicular distance from the
point to the line of action of the force.

1004118B6A604317B124F2ED90416B71.description: Moment of a force about a point.

1C8AB9E2430647139D09688562AA2CDD.description:
Conditions for equilibrium for two or three coplanar
forces acting at a point. Appreciation of the meaning of
equilibrium in the context of an object at rest or moving
with constant velocity.

E3BF467B9421479FA437A5BA010E4713.description:
Problems may be solved either by the use of resolved forces
or the use of a closed triangle.

A231885FC42540A5B86ED3504A85D432.description:
Examples should include components of forces along and
perpendicular to an inclined plane.

8E49D86262C94E428999822DEA4172AF.description:
Resolution of vectors into two components at right angles to
each other.

AF91875FFCDD407986C9C0389B488CDF.description:
Addition of vectors by calculation or scale drawing. Calculations will be limited to two vectors at right angles.
Scale drawings may involve vectors at angles other than 90
°.

DA48CABA52E8499D9F4AB4FF33238A07.description:
Examples should include:
velocity/speed, mass, force/weight, acceleration,
displacement/distance.

72DAFDBF75764CCA8E17B2F3A9A75CEE.description:
Material and modal dispersion. Students are expected to understand the principles and
consequences of pulse broadening and absorption.

668A78FC6EE8448097522E90EB00E66B.description:
Simple treatment of fibre optics including the function of
the cladding. Optical fibres will be limited to step index only.

E02511DE37074C3DBA132CBD7CA86675.description: Total internal reflection sin θ𝒸 = n₁ / n₂

973FB9B03CEA4850BBFEE38E4D031A6B.description: Snell’s law of refraction for a boundary n₁sin θ₁ = n₂sin θ₂

4B08E69DB8EE43D389AB6BC0A092464E.description:
Students should recall that the refractive index of air is
approximately 1.

B98A4F947D234AE5939CBCFAC48E85CB.description: Refractive index of a substance, n = c / cₛ

0EF8B8A06D8545C6942A11DDDB0BF949.description: Plane transmission diffraction grating at normal incidence.

55538B614D134BD69D037C76CFD766E7.description:
Qualitative treatment of the variation of the width of the
central diffraction maximum with wavelength and slit
width. The graph of intensity against angular separation is
not required.

8776DCDD2DF648D5A71EC08D24DD4F4B.description:
Appearance of the diffraction pattern from a single slit using
monochromatic and white light.

4304584D45424B749BBC4BFB07B78B8C.description:
Required practical 2: Investigation of interference effects
to include the Young’s slit experiment and interference by a
diffraction grating.

5DCAD20C9817448E96D7BD0F65F8705F.description:
Appreciation of how knowledge and understanding of nature
of electromagnetic radiation has changed over time.

951E0F18A6824F92942410A81BFC4A70.description:
Students will be expected to describe and explain interference
produced with sound and electromagnetic waves.

BB7FE99BAC124811913881D2AAA4210B.description:
Students are expected to show awareness of safety issues
associated with using lasers.

C91F5E242A8C4C47A3AE52F9F161BAB3.description: Production of interference pattern using white light.

CB2AADEC9C2F42808DB58540B86D896A.description:
Young’s double-slit experiment: the use of two coherent
sources or the use of a single source with double slits to
produce an interference pattern.

E3C819B6FF6246D5A2C02BD25BD905AC.description:
Interference and diffraction using a laser as a source of
monochromatic light.

6DF09F4D8FB0434CA19F923510112164.description:
Required practical 1: Investigation into the variation of
the frequency of stationary waves on a string with length,
tension and mass per unit length of the string.

FC8EDBB4AAEA405AA2BC1CA9A9DF63B2.description:
Stationary waves on strings will be described in terms of
harmonics. The terms fundamental (for first harmonic) and
overtone will not be used.

058B442764FD48B9985FFBC7FAE00C2D.description:
Stationary waves formed on a string and those produced
with microwaves and sound waves should be considered.

28D444C6359B4EF5B90127D4BEFA0476.description:
A graphical explanation of formation of stationary waves will
be expected.

969873A86594416DAEC6A522C9628E74.description:
The formation of stationary waves by two waves of the same
frequency travelling in opposite directions.

4C532C75AA1C4C8D86909DE32B9DA227.description:
f = 1 / (2l) x √(T
/ μ) for first harmonic.

289A7C4B9AE547EA811C714829C496EB.description: Principle of superposition of waves and formation of stationary waves

96F529D8ED144762B34BB1E88D276CE0.description:
Applications of polarisers to include Polaroid material and
the alignment of aerials for transmission and reception.

B5A18CC77A35400FA7E986446D16C164.description: Polarisation as evidence for the nature of transverse waves.

8C5C6E81DF9341D18DBAC994514C3A4A.description:
Students will be expected to know the direction of
displacement of particles/fields relative to the direction of
energy propagation and that all electromagnetic waves
travel at the same speed in a vacuum.

7156492E9084405297F87A2A4CAA4430.description:
Nature of longitudinal and transverse waves.
Examples to include: sound, electromagnetic waves, and
waves on a string.

F781CF4644EC44B195589E4469858C26.description:
Phase difference may be measured as angles (radians and
degrees) or as fractions of a cycle.

98458270C54A4D1D98949426B60F8A55.description: amplitude, frequency, wavelength, speed, phase, phase difference, c = f λ,  f = 1/T

91F85ECDABB04E03B8266752E2B7FF06.description: Oscillation of the particles of the medium;

2D3E08A27D134D0E86630B68BE735B8C.description:
Appreciation that such changes need to be evaluated
through peer review and validated by the scientific
community.

3766708276314C0B87B541D3ACC972EC.description:
Appreciation of how knowledge and understanding of the
nature of matter changes over time.

A3E4A79BEC484FE7A10CC29144EB2183.description:
Students should be able to explain how and why the amount
of diffraction changes when the momentum of the particle is
changed.

130F2DB4EDBB4F86AE4AA1AD73AB97DD.description: de Broglie wavelength λ = h / (mv) where mv is the momentum.

F0C19066774E4A3FA2D6321BD438B639.description:
Details of particular methods of particle diffraction are not
expected.

09F59B1BEA334FAB904E49D0A1F8B049.description:
Students should know that electron diffraction suggests that
particles possess wave properties and the photoelectric
effect suggests that electromagnetic waves have a
particulate nature.

432C76C10B844DB8ABDF1DE4F8689F48.description: hf = E₁ − E₂ In questions, energy levels may be quoted in J or eV.

886C9535B2844BA28F40180DC095CAD7.description:
Line spectra (eg of atomic hydrogen) as evidence for
transitions between discrete energy levels in atoms.

8D4A75C708EC4B36A32B4E888F235631.description:
The electron volt. Students will be expected to be able to convert eV into J
and vice versa.

2F98C1C4024B439E97A18A8A4EED7FD3.description:
Ionisation and excitation; understanding of ionisation and
excitation in the fluorescent tube.

5EB1510077C6419FBFB6E70E64F307DC.description: Photoelectric equation: h f = φ + Ek (max)

EDE2FD6E52B049A8AB81E6B636E51593.description:
Threshold frequency; photon explanation of threshold
frequency.

84DB530D601F4B4D9FA321C206256D27.description:
Students should recognise that energy and momentum are
conserved in interactions.

536F4B33E2DA44C89B660285DCC445B7.description:
Application of the conservation laws for charge, baryon
number, lepton number and strangeness to particle
interactions. The necessary data will be provided in
questions for particles outside those specified.

FAF9B85BC8AC4F269098BC8FE9A92A8D.description: Change of quark character in β− and in β+ decay.

D0EAE3FF5CD543A69847523BEB646208.description: The decay of the neutron should be known.

84CC4104E1F64B44A47E0D08DB5C424B.description:
Combinations of quarks and antiquarks required for baryons
(proton and neutron only), antibaryons (antiproton and
antineutron only) and mesons (pion and kaon only).

28DF68BAF4F342768972A3BB9D993415.description:
Properties of quarks and antiquarks: charge, baryon number
and strangeness. Only knowledge of up (u), down (d) and strange (s) quarks
and their antiquarks will be tested.

329FB18D252C488AB2C85FFD9D5E4336.description:
Appreciation that particle physics relies on the collaborative
efforts of large teams of scientists and engineers to validate
new knowledge.

21785CEE0A91454083F2FB6CF1BC0380.description: Strangeness can change by 0, +1 or -1 in weak interactions.

D2668719CB174BCDB0C76E652EA0914A.description: Conservation of strangeness in strong interactions.

1374A5B4E8A647DF8496DAC7AE2E8D81.description:
Strangeness (symbol s) as a quantum number to reflect the
fact that strange particles are always created in pairs.

44C5722B1348421E9D80BFEE8461417F.description:
Strange particles as particles that are produced through the
strong interaction and decay through the weak interaction
(eg kaons).

F28C426600D54207B555AA340B61202D.description: The muon as a particle that decays into an electron.

153EC4C1E6DB46C99E2C61CA40432B3F.description:
Lepton number as a quantum number; conservation of
lepton number for muon leptons and for electron leptons.

E0B0B8EBB885467EBC6D04FF6C85BA82.description:
Leptons: electron, muon, neutrino (electron and muon types
only) and their antiparticles.

C74573BA6556405790D4288D78C760D5.description: The kaon as a particle that can decay into pions.

1823F681723F4B0CB3F478DD44760D22.description: The pion as the exchange particle of the strong nuclear force.

ACBDF3315C8A436C9206FFE22582B3C8.description:
The proton is the only stable baryon into which other
baryons eventually decay.

991126C5020F4C70A49D11DB5409D736.description: Baryon number as a quantum number. Conservation of baryon number.

0710620C4E0648BB880B210ABD5C54F1.description:
The two classes of hadrons:
•• baryons (proton, neutron) and antibaryons
(antiproton and antineutron)
•• mesons (pion, kaon).

C4B14864D4C14C45B2C37A69C997FC83.description: Hadrons are subject to the strong interaction.

CF840CBD2FC444D39B6591264E69680A.description:
Simple diagrams to represent the above reactions or
interactions in terms of incoming and outgoing particles and
exchange particles.

BBA06A9341824AAB9504C1EA6EFC9BCB.description:
The weak interaction limited to β−and β+ decay, electron
capture and electron–proton collisions; W+ and W− as the
exchange particles.

248FD99D1F4445A7A1EABFEC8409C0BF.description:
The electromagnetic force; virtual photons as the
exchange particle.

1F63F3EE95B14318A124312CD45DE826.description:
The concept of exchange particles to explain forces
between elementary particles.

49E3166AB4C14EE882657B2288CE2AFB.description:
Four fundamental interactions: gravity, electromagnetic,
weak nuclear, strong nuclear. (The strong nuclear force may
be referred to as the strong interaction.)

F54EAB9DA73A424E9165580849026523.description:
Knowledge of annihilation and pair production and the
energies involved.

680FC64BC4C445C99051077936912EFF.description:
Photon model of electromagnetic radiation, the Planck
constant.

6ECA2E8DF0844DE4BAF5E47D83D065B0.description:
Students should know that the positron, antiproton,
antineutron and antineutrino are the antiparticles of the
electron, proton, neutron and neutrino respectively.

6EE0DFC5A7144603A144DEB3AB23B76A.description:
Comparison of particle and antiparticle masses, charge and
rest energy in MeV.

7BC1AE5335184DDE96380EFB6E5D89D8.description:
For every type of particle, there is a corresponding
antiparticle.

ECA8CA8AFE14401E8B50A05FAFB29EFE.description:
The existence of the neutrino was hypothesised to account
for conservation of energy in beta decay.

056C7225416349AAB22403025DFE5E42.description:
Equations for alpha decay, β− decay including the need for
the neutrino.

685D53F464754B98B093A6EE6D7FD520.description: Unstable nuclei; alpha and beta decay.

A3BB88C6D23244819C96AB45FBD69A1B.description:
The strong nuclear force; its role in keeping the nucleus
stable; short-range attraction up to approximately 3 fm,
very-short range repulsion closer than approximately 0.5 fm.

7FF4C397E487452E91C981EFE7D3B54D.description: Meaning of isotopes and the use of isotopic data.

9406CCE0730A4B85AC9AF4E8473DB401.description: Students should be familiar with the ᴬ𝓏X notation.

892068E94C904A039C471ECA2E87ADA9.description: Proton number Z, nucleon number A, nuclide notation.

D71789357F3D42658EEA7423B9E8A92D.description:
Specific charge of the proton and the electron, and of nuclei
and ions.

4186D5E01BFB43F2813036A541A74433.description:
Simple model of the atom, including the proton, neutron
and electron. Charge and mass of the proton, neutron and
electron in SI units and relative units.

065E313B3B824638B9B7CF2D7A547135.description: Estimation of approximate values of physical quantities.

976D31DE95A6447FA9744FE4C3F4CD82.description:
Determine the uncertainties in the gradient and intercept of a
straight-line graph. Individual points on the graph may or may not have
associated error bars.

F2636450A0994AB9932D8E2B9B7E8162.description:
Represent uncertainty in a data point on a graph using error
bars.

F6C20E84866D49BBB1B4EED329D60525.description:
Combination of absolute and percentage uncertainties. Students should be able to combine
uncertainties in cases where the
measurements that give rise to the
uncertainties are added, subtracted,
multiplied, divided, or raised to
powers.

4FE819FBFAA447BB9E324539060625B4.description:
Absolute, fractional and percentage uncertainties represent
uncertainty in the final answer for a quantity.

6980758A607A458497B240573F1586F4.description:
Precision, repeatability, reproducibility, resolution and
accuracy.

57C8FD9790394F3F87BCD296FF15D27A.description:
Students should be able to convert between different units of
the same quantity, eg J and eV, J and kW h.

B7EB84695E94429FA7BA7C6C406438CB.description:
Students should be able to use the prefixes:
T, G, M, k, c, m, μ, n, p, f,

FAA47469D1ED4653A30D1DC887FAC536.description:
Knowledge and use of the SI prefixes, values and standard
form.

189D5DB8B8A143B59F01C237C7BF22A3.description: Fundamental (base) units. Use of mass, length, time, amount of substance, temperature, electric current and their associated SI units.

859995335B884E1792D9A8BE91DCAE58.description: Use of SI units and their prefixes
